$!You may need to tell DVLA if you have had a heart transplant.$!

%You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don't tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you're involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.%

##Car or motorcycle licence

You don't need to tell DVLA, but you should stop driving for at least 1 month and only start driving again when you doctor tells you that you are safe to do so. Read leaflet 'CLE1066' for more information.

$D [Download 'CLE1066 - Car or motorcycle drivers with heart conditions' (PDF, 129KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_192828.pdf "CLE1066 leaflet"){:rel="external"}$D

##Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form VOCH1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

$D [Download 'VOCH1' (PDF, 394KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_065302.pdf "Download 'VOCH1 questionnaire' (PDF, 394KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

*[DVLA]: Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency
overview: Find out when you need to tell DVLA if you have had a heart transplant - download the correct forms to tell DVLA
title: Heart transplants and driving
